passages.text: Anatoliy A Shal (971) 4561- 2005

Russia's activity data for July was, on balance, softer than expected. We have lowered our 3Q growth forecast to \(0.5\% q / q\) , saar, from \(1.25\%\) previously, and suspect that risks are probably still skewed to the downside. Continued softness in growth data amid better- behaved inflation suggests that the CBR will continue the easing cycle in the coming months. Moreover, given the perceived distribution of risks for growth and inflation, this will likely result in more front- loaded cuts in the near- term. We now expect the CBR to cut 200bp to \(16.0\%\) (17.0 previously) at the upcoming September meeting and the key rate to end the year at \(14.0\%\) (15.0).

Industrial production slowed to \(0.7\%\) oya in July, below expectations (JPME 2.2, consensus 1.5). The surprise was partly due to upward revisions to 2024 IP trajectory, which lifted the base of comparison, but sequential momentum was also soft. We estimate IP declined \(0.3\% m / m\) , sa, in July, the fourth decline in the past seven months, with mining bouncing \(0.9\%\) and manufacturing contracting \(1.4\%\) (Figure 1). Within manufacturing, the weakness was fairly broad- based, led by defence- related industries last month.
Figure 1: Industrial production - Russia

Other production- side indicators were mixed. Construction works bounced \(1.6\% m / m\) , sa, following two months of declines, transport turnover declined \(1.3\%\) and wholesale turnover dropped \(0.4\%\) . The index of basic sectors, which covers more than half of GDP, was down \(0.2\%\) , sa, on the month, following a \(0.4\%\) drop in the previous month (Figure 2).
Europe Economic Research
Figure 2: Index of basic sectors - Russia Index, Dec06=100, sa by J.P. Morgan

On the demand side, consumers have fared better in recent months. Retail sales rose \(0.7\% m / m\) , sa, in July and are up \(- 4.0\%\) saar from three months ago; consumption of services slid \(0.1\%\) on the month but is up \(- 1.6\%\) 3m saar. Consumption remains supported by solid labor income gains. Unemployment has remained steady at a very low \(2.2\%\) , sa, in past three months, while nominal wage growth has been running in the mid- teens. The latter implies substantial real wage growth ( \(5.1\%\) oya in July), running ahead of productivity gains, which will likely maintain inflation inertia in the services part of CPI basket in the coming months. Yet, business surveys already point to a softening in labor demand. We anticipate a cooling of the labor market to follow output growth as a whole with a lag, but mostly via work hours and pay growth rather than headline employment.

The August flash Polish CPI was softer than expected: \(2.8\%\) oya from \(3.1\%\) in July versus \(2.9\%\) expected. The available details imply core at \(0\% m / m\) , rather soft compared to both prior months and recent August prints ( \(0.3\% m / m\) over Jun- July and also \(0.3\%\) in August 2023 and 2024). Thus, Poland continues to display rather soft core inflation compared to its peers (Figure 3). On an over- year- ago basis, core (national definition) likely dropped to \(3\%\) from \(3.3\%\) , a tick below our forecast of \(3.1\%\) .
Figure 3: CE4 momentum in comparable core (HICP based)

The National Bank of Hungary kept rates unchanged this week at 6.50% and communication remained cautious. This challenges our forecast for a rate cut in September, but we have highlighted the rising possibility of a delay to December.While the rate meeting this week was largely a non-event, the chances of a rate cut in September are lower than before as NBH did not move to signal it at all.

Next week the National Bank of Poland will meet to decide on rates. Soft inflation data for August supports the consensus view of a 25bp NBP cut next week to 4.75%. Our view has been of rates remaining unchanged for several reasons: erratic NBP behavior, resilient economic growth and wage dynam-ics. While recognizing that the chances of a rate cut have increased after the CPI data, we continue to expect a cut only in November.
**Week of September 1-5**

Our newcaster points to \(0.5\%\) q/q sa in 2Q25, down from \(1.0\%\) in 1Q25; we expect a modest slowdown in growth across sectors, driven by tight financial conditions. IP increased by \(0.7\%\) q/q in 2Q25, compared to \(1.7\%\) in 1Q25. The services sector showed no growth in 2Q25, compared to \(3.1\%\) growth in 1Q25. Construction slowed to \(0.8\%\) q/q in 2Q25, while retail sales growth remained robust at \(3.9\%\) q/q in 2Q25. GDP likely grew by \(4.2\%\) oya in 2Q25 (compared to \(2.0\%\) in 1Q25), supported by favorable calendar effects, although quarterly growth is expected to decelerate.
WedConsumer pricesSep 3% change10:00amMayJunJulAugConsumer prices%oya35.435.033.532.6%m/m1.51.42.11.8Producer prices%oya23.124.524.2—%m/m2.52.51.7—Core CPI (I)%oya35.435.634.732.9%m/m2.41.91.71.6

Monthly price gains will be driven by food, services, and tobacco prices. Service inflation remained high, led by education and rent in August. Food inflation likely increased by \(2.3\%\) m/m due to the rise in prices of fresh fruits & vegetables, and bread, after three months of stability.
Source: CBRT, Local sources, J.P. Morgan
